div.head:
Embleme 30. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Luna is as requisite to Sol as a henne to a cocke.

lg.l: What can you doe dear Sol! alone, if I
Joyne not as henne with cocke to multiply?
Or can I Luna Natures guifts expresse
Without your ayde? noe, grant mee some redresse.
Hee's but a foole those to confine apart
Whome Nature would have joynd in mind and heart.

div.head: Discourse 30.
div.ab:
Avicenne in his booke of the Soule divers times admonisheth, that noe-
eggs are to be taken for art, but onely of those henns, which had a cock:
that is, the fæminine subject avayles nothing without the masculine-
virtue, and on the contrary, nor a cocke profitable without a henne:
for both these sexes must be joynd together in the Philosophicall coupe,
that multiplication may be made: The Philosophers doe indeed use
the similitude taken from a cocke, because in the first place hee is-
more correspondent to the power of Sulphur, than any other male of
birds, one being able to serve many henns, and not easily suffering a
rivall in the same dunghill, thinking himselfe convenient and suffi
cient for everyone. Hee is the bird of Mars, transformd, as the Poets
fable, from the youth Gallus, who was entrusted to observe Sol, that-
hee might not discover the adultery of Mars with Venus, and very
Martiall in fight, contending with his adversary even to death: In-
the Philosophicall worke hee repræsents Sol, as the henne doth Luna:
there is therefore the same necessity of joyning Sol with Luna, as a-
cocke with a henne: The cocke is allso consecrated to Sol, at whose-
approach hee riseth, and goes to sleep with him: hee often looks up to-
heaven, and erects his hooked tayle upright: hee fights against Serpents in
defence of his henns: hee is an acceptable messenger of light and Latona-
being præsent at her labour: Latona indeed brought forth Sol and Luna,
and therefore hee is appropriated to the mother and Sonne: But Sol,-
Luna, and Latona doe in Chymicall subjects agree, soe allso the cocke
and henne: but these allso proceded from an egge, and againe doe-
lay eggs for the production of young chickens; soe allso doe the Philoso
phers eggs turne into birds of the same kind, provided they be kept-
warme with temperate heat, as is the heat of a brooding henne, which
endures continually: For whereas amongst other birds the male allso
sitts upon the eggs, the cocke alone shews himselfe free from this
office or burthen; and therefore all the care and pains of hatching the
eggs, and producing chickens lyes upon the henne; where her sedulity
and diligence may be observed, how hastily Shee eats and drinks, and
unloads her belly, and presently runns backe to her eggs, before they be-
cold: Then with what force and violence Shee defends her chickens,
with what tendernesse Shee receives and covers them being naked under
her wings, with what a voyce, as with a bell, Shee calls and keeps them-
together, with what study Shee breaks the harder crums or seeds for-
them, and præsents them with her beake, as on a knife, this worke of-
nature is worthy of admiration. And all these things are, that man
may neither want eggs nor chickens for aliment: After the same man
ner the Philosopher or artist doth most diligently and providently-
Discourse 30.
proceed in all his operations; For hee picks up eggs there where a cocke-
hath been, trying them whether they be adle, after that hee cleanseth-
præpares, and disposseth them in his vessells, as nests, and administers due
heat, whereby the subjects mixd together daily act and suffer one by-
another, till after a long time passing through various colours they come
to one colour and essence: In which operation Solution, congulation,
Sublimation, ascension, descension, distillation, calcination and fixion
as intermediate are perfected: for a hard and compact thing cannot-
be altered, therefore Solution is præmised, that is may be made liquid
and soft: and where a thing is dissolved, it is convenient allso to be-
coagulated, not to its former hardnesse but a honyish tractability;-
Sublimation separates the pure from the impure, and makes a thing
vile more worthy, the inferiour superiour; and therefore this nei
ther ought to be wanting, for it is as the mistresse and directresse-
of all: when sublimation is made, some parts ascend higher, which
is ascension, and others againe descend, and soe descension is made:
Distillation allso clarifyes the whole being often interposed, and that
which remaynes in the bottome is calcined: then both are fixed, and
soe the worke is completed. But if a man gather all these parti
cular operations under a generall, which is Coction, hee will not-
erre much from the purpose: for as soe many chickens as there are,
which runne here and there dispersedly, doe resort to one mother or
nurce the henne, soe doe soe many severall wayes of operating con
curre to the womans worke, that is, coction alone: It is Luna, which-
comes to be exalted to the sublimity of Sol, for whose sake all these
things are done, that is, durable matrimony is intended between Sol-
and Luna, which if effected, all legations, desponsations, copulations,
dubitatious, ex. will cease. and the bed and flesh of both will be one,
mutuall and constant love, æternall peace, and an indissoluble alli
ance: Sol without Luna is of noe great esteeme, and Luna without
Sol of meane and sordid condition: But Shee receives splendour, and
dignity, with strength or constancy of mind and body from Sol her-
husband, and Sol from Luna multiplication of offspring, and pro
pagation of kind: hereupon Sayth the Rosary: If onely one of them-
Should be in our stone, the medicine would never flow easily, nor,-
yeild the tincture, and if it should yeild, it would not tinge, unlesse
for see much as allso the remainder would be, and the Mercury would
evaporate in fume, because the receptacle of the tincture would not
be in it: And Geber in his booke of examinations proves, that if Sol-
and Luna be incorporated together with art, they are not easily-
separated. . . . . . . . . . . .
